page.title: 15La Cotte de St Brelade
page.content: In the cliffs at Ouaisne, St. Brelades there is a cave. It does not look much like a cave today as the rock making up the roof has fallen. The cave is of great archaeological importance. Various excavations have revealed evidence of the cave's occupation at different times by Neanderthal man and by some species of now extinct animals, e.g. Woolly Mammoth and Woolly Rhinoceros. The latest dig was carried out between 1961 and 1980 by a team from Cambridge University led by Charles McBurney. They have since blocked off the site, intending it to be re-opened in later years when certain investigative techniques have been improved over today's standards. Prince Charles was one of the diggers on the site in 1968.
